title: Insecure Storage and Overly Permissive  API Keys in Android App
vulnerability_information:
#Description:
Most often Developers for their ease of use,leave API keys and some sensitive keys ,Tokens as hardcoded strings,which isn't really a good ideas as it can result in Leaks of sensitive information getting in Wrong Hands which indeed can results in Data theft and Tampering with how the application deals with the data, and API requests the application Makes.

==I found a bunch of API keys,Tokens.==

#To Check API keys leaks Sensitive Information or not
https://github.com/streaak/keyhacks

#Steps to reproduce.
1.Decomiple the app.
2.Look for sensitive information


#Proof of Concept:
Screenshots has been attached as a proof of concept.

## Impact

If an attacker decompiles your apk, and extracts your token, they can indeed maliciously send traffic on your behalf.
This is the case with pretty much every single one of the web  companies out there (google included).
The main thing to know however, is that it is rarely useful for people to do this. Polluting someone else's data  while possible, isn't exactly a profitable thing to do. You can also create server-side filters to help prevent this thing from happening.
vulnerability_information_html:
Description:

Most often Developers for their ease of use,leave API keys and some sensitive keys ,Tokens as hardcoded strings,which isn't really a good ideas as it can result in Leaks of sensitive information getting in Wrong Hands which indeed can results in Data theft and Tampering with how the application deals with the data, and API requests the application Makes.

I found a bunch of API keys,Tokens.

To Check API keys leaks Sensitive Information or not

https://github.com/streaak/keyhacks

Steps to reproduce.

1.Decomiple the app.
2.Look for sensitive information

Proof of Concept:

Screenshots has been attached as a proof of concept.

Impact

If an attacker decompiles your apk, and extracts your token, they can indeed maliciously send traffic on your behalf.
This is the case with pretty much every single one of the web companies out there (google included).
The main thing to know however, is that it is rarely useful for people to do this. Polluting someone else's data while possible, isn't exactly a profitable thing to do. You can also create server-side filters to help prevent this thing from happening.

Thanks for your report and happy bug hunting

activities.message:
Thank you for your response.

We realize this has caused some confusion, so please let us apologize and clarify the situation here.  We received a large number of reports in quick succession around the tokens in `strings.xml`, and we had to make some decisions regarding which researchers received a bounty for this single finding. There was never any intention to reward any researcher a bounty for each token reported. While we could have only offered a single bounty for the first researcher to report this file to us, we instead chose to reward certain other researchers as well, when they provided more detail regarding a particular token's risk and the potential impact of the token being leaked. We ensured that those who reported actionable tokens quickly, such as yourself, received a bounty, in order to be fair, but this is not a case where one researcher got a bounty that another researcher could have received. More specifically, regardless of how many tokens were included in a report, **no one researcher was going to receive more than a single bounty for reporting API tokens exposed in `strings.xml`**. Once again, apologies for any confusion this may have caused, and please let us know if you have any further questions.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
